Introduction



The Woodland Generation Station (WGS) is located at 920 Woodland Avenue in Modesto, California. The WGS stores and uses aqueous ammonia (29-percent aqueous ammonia solution) in a selective catalytic reduction (SCR) system to control nitrogen oxide (NOx) emissions. Using and storing aqueous ammonia can be a hazard if it is not handled properly. WGS personnel take their safety obligations very seriously and ensure that operators involved in the use of aqueous ammonia are trained and knowledgeable in the chemical hazards associated with their jobs. The following Risk Management Plan (RMP) describes what could happen if there were to be an accident, some of the steps taken to ensure a safely operating power plant, and how chemical emergencies are handled. This RMP complies with the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accidental Release Prevention under Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Part 68, and the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program under Title 19 of the California Code of Regulations (CCR), Division 2, Chapter 4.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The WGS accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates proven technology, staff training on operation and maintenance practices, and tested management system practices. Applicable federal procedures and state of California procedures are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures. 



WGS facility management recognizes the responsibility to make the environment, community, and employee safety a primary part of daily concerns. The WGS is committed to being a responsible member within the community by giving top priority to operating in a safe and environmentally sound manner. The WGS is dedicated to developing an environmentally responsible energy resource compatible with community need

s. The prevention of accidents and protection of its employees, property, and the general public are essential to the efficient and successful completion of every project undertaken by the WGS. The WGS requires active injury and illness prevention as an important element of production on a daily basis.



It is the policy of the WGS that every employee is entitled to a safe and healthful place in which to work and live. The WGS incorporates the concepts of environmental responsibility and productivity with safety resulting in efficiency and productivity. 



As part of the WGS's obligation to protect the integrity of human, environmental, physical, and financial resources, and to conserve and efficiently utilize those resources, the WGS will:

- Comply fully with laws regulating environmental protection and employee health and safety.

- Furnish work places free of recognized hazards likely to cause injury to employees, the public, or the environment.

- Train employees in safe and environmentally conscious practices and require compliance with environmental, health, and safety regulations, policies, and procedures.

- Provide a professional staff to maintain and support environmental, health, and safety programs.



General Facility and Regulated Substances Information



The WGS is a 185-megawatt (MW) electrical generation facility equipped with two gas turbine engine powered generators, referred to as WGS Units 1 and 2; six internal combustion reciprocating engine powered electrical generators, referred to as WGS Unit 3; and associated equipment. All eight engines are fueled by natural gas. Power generated by the WGS is transmitted to the grid at 69 kilovolts (kV) through subtransmission lines connected to the Modesto Irrigation District (MID) Enslen Substation.



The WGS stores 29 percent aqueous ammonia solution in a single 14,000-gallon aboveground storage tank. The maximum quantity of aqueous ammonia (29 percent aqueous ammonia solution) stored at a given ti

me is 12,600 gallons, or approximately 27,400 pounds of ammonia in solution. This quantity exceeds the EPA Risk Management Program threshold of 20,000 pounds for concentrations 20 percent or greater and the CalARP Program threshold of 500 pounds of ammonia in solution; therefore, this process is subject to the EPA Risk Management Program and CalARP Program regulations. The aqueous ammonia process at the WGS qualifies for Program Level 2.



Aqueous ammonia is used at the WGS in an SCR system to control emissions of NOx from natural gas combustion. Aqueous ammonia is vaporized and injected into the exhaust gas stream from WGS Units 1 and 2 and then passed through a catalyst bed. At WGS Unit 3, however, aqueous ammonia is sprayed into the exhaust stream in liquid form and is vaporized and mixed directly in the exhaust before entering the SCR grid. In the presence of the catalyst, the ammonia and NOx react to form nitrogen and water vapor, thereby reducing NOx emissions. Aqueous ammonia is a regulated toxic substance under the EPA Risk Management Program and CalARP Program. This RMP addresses the aqueous ammonia process at the WGS.



Summary of the Five-Year Accident History



In the past 5 years, the WGS has had no accidents involving aqueous ammonia that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



Summary of the Emergency Response Program



The WGS has developed an Emergency Action Plan, which establishes emergency response procedures designed to protect personnel, limit damage to the environment, and ensure that proper notifications go to the appropriate government agencies. The Emergency Action Plan details the response procedures, protective measures, levels of training, regulatory notification requirements, and post-incident investigation procedures. The Emergency Action Plan also identifies emergency assembly areas, e

vacuation routes, and related procedures to be undertaken during emergency scenarios.



In the event of an aqueous ammonia release, the highest-ranking WGS operations person onsite will assess whether the release is controllable (i.e., incidental and easily contained) or uncontrollable. If the release is controllable, trained WGS personnel will perform the tasks necessary to accomplish containment and mitigation of the release. If the release is uncontrollable, the MID Control Center will notify the Modesto Fire Department. The Modesto Fire Department will handle spill/release response and mitigation. 



The Emergency Action Plan is shared with and periodically reviewed by the Stanislaus County Department of Environmental Resources. The facility will work closely with the Modesto Fire Department to coordinate response actions by submitting updated Hazardous Materials Business Plans to the Modesto Fire Department, inviting Stanislaus County Department of Environmental Resources staff to attend hazard reviews of the aqueous ammonia system, and inviting Modesto Fire Department staff to tour the WGS and the aqueous ammonia system. Additionally, employees will be trained on the Emergency Action Plan when initially hired, and all employees will receive annual refresher training on emergency response.



Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps 



The prevention program for the aqueous ammonia process is briefly summarized below. 



Safety Information



The WGS will compile and maintain up-to-date safety information related to the regulated substances, processes, and equipment. This information is used to identify and understand the hazards in operating the aqueous ammonia process. The safety information includes material safety data sheets, a process description, maximum intended inventory, safe operating limits, equipment specifications, and codes and standards used to design, build, and operate the system.



Hazar

d Review



The WGS will conduct hazard reviews to improve safety and reduce the consequences of accidental releases of aqueous ammonia. The hazard review identifies the process hazards, opportunities for equipment malfunctions or human errors, safeguards used to control hazards, and steps used to detect or monitor releases. The hazard review will be revalidated or updated at least once every 5 years.



Operating Procedures



The WGS will maintain up-to-date, accurate, and written operating procedures that provide clear instructions for the aqueous ammonia process. Operating procedures are required for applicable stages of system operation, including initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown operations, normal shutdown, startup following normal and emergency shutdown, consequences of deviations, steps required to correct or avoid deviations, and equipment inspections.



Training



WGS staff will complete and maintain all training requirements for his or her position and ensure that all supporting documentation is filed in the control room. Employees must be trained on aqueous ammonia operating or maintenance procedures, safety and health hazards, and safe work practices before they can operate or maintain the covered process. The WGS will develop and maintain the written employee training program and associated training materials and training records. The training program includes initial training, refresher training, and documentation. Refresher training is conducted at least every 3 years.



Maintenance



The WGS will implement the maintenance program to ensure the continued integrity of the equipment in the aqueous ammonia process. An effective maintenance program addresses equipment testing and inspection, preventative maintenance schedules, personnel training, and correction of equipment deficiencies. Preventative maintenance will be performed according to equipment manufacturers' recommendations. Work orders will be sto

red electronically, to be completed by WGS staff as the schedule permits.



Compliance Audits



Compliance audits will be completed and documented for the covered process at least once every 3 years. Compliance audits for the aqueous ammonia process will be performed by a team that includes at least one person knowledgeable in the aqueous ammonia process and an audit leader knowledgeable in the EPA Risk Management Program and CalARP Program requirements and audit techniques. The compliance audits evaluate the prevention program elements and their implementation for compliance with the EPA Risk Management Program and CalARP Program regulations.



Incident Investigation



Following an incident that resulted in or could have reasonably resulted in a release of aqueous ammonia, WGS staff will initiate incident investigation procedures and ensure that any resulting corrective actions are addressed and documented. The investigation will begin as soon as possible and no later than 48 hours after the incident.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety 



The WGS conducted an initial aqueous ammonia hazard review prior to increasing the quantity of aqueous ammonia stored onsite to assess the safety of the process and identify causes of potential aqueous ammonia releases. The hazard review team developed a list of risk-reduction measures to improve safety at the WGS. Details of the recommendations from the hazard review can be found in the Prevention Program document in Section 3 of this RMP. Some of the risk reduction measures considered include implementing routine maintenance procedures for pressure-relief valves, installing bollards near the ammonia storage tank and associated piping, confirming vendor inspection procedures, and providing contractors with project-specific safety tailgate meetings. The implementation of these recommendations will further improve the safety of the aqueous ammonia system.
